DOCNAME: MANOILESCU AND DOBRESCU v. ROMANIA AND RUSSIA
TEXT: CARDINAL . The applicants , Mr PERSON and PERSON , are NORP nationals who were born in DATE and DATE respectively . The first applicant lives in PERSON ( GPE ) and the second in GPE ( GPE ) . They were represented before the ORG by Mr PERSON , a lawyer practising in GPE .
CARDINAL . NORP The facts of the case , as submitted by the parties , may be summarised as follows .
CARDINAL . The applicants are heirs of DATE , who in DATE purchased QUANTITY . m of land in PERSON , near GPE , on which he had a house built ( “ the building in NORP ” ) .
CARDINAL . NORP In a judgment of CARDINAL DATE , ORG sentenced DATE imprisonment for subversive activities against the ORG . In DATE he died in prison .

CARDINAL . In a decision of CARDINAL DATE , ORG , on an application by PERSON , quashed that judgment and acquitted DATE on all the charges on the ground that the essential elements of the offence of which he had been convicted had not been made out .
CARDINAL . In Order no . DATE of DATE , made during the Second World War , the building in PERSON was requisitioned by ORG and placed at the disposal of ORG ( GPE ) .

CARDINAL . On DATE , following ORG , GPE was held responsible for the war damage caused to the ORG and was ordered to make reparation through transfers of NORP assets in foreign countries such as GPE .

CARDINAL . Law no . CARDINAL of DATE on the return to the GPE authorities of NORP assets in NORP territory in accordance with the decisions taken at FAC authorised ORG to determine the procedure for returning property to the GPE authorities designated by ORG in GPE .

CARDINAL . On DATE and CARDINAL DATE ORG decided that assets that belonged to NORP natural and artificial persons and were registered in the lists kept by ORG Property were to be transferred to the authorities designated by ORG under PERSON no . CARDINAL . Among the immovable property thus transferred to the NORP authorities was a building at CARDINAL Dr FAC in GPE , owned by a private individual , PERSON
CARDINAL . In that context , by order of ORG , GPE 's property was again requisitioned on DATE . On DATE it was allocated to ORG .

CARDINAL . In DATE the building in question was nationalised by GPE under Decree no . CARDINAL/CARDINAL on nationalisation . It was assigned to the GPE embassy in GPE , as is apparent from the lists appended to the decree .

CARDINAL . In Decree no . CARDINAL of DATE the ORG of ORG of GPE authorised ORG to carry out an exchange of immovable property with the GPE on behalf of ORG . The decree empowered the Ministry to transfer to the GPE title to a number of houses in PERSON ( known collectively as “ Adesgo ” ) belonging to ORG and , in return , to receive title to CARDINAL properties in the GPE 's possession in GPE and GPE . The exchange of property was approved on DATE in decision no . CARDINAL of ORG of the Romanian People 's Republic .

CARDINAL . In Decree no . CARDINAL of CARDINAL DATE ORG of the Romanian People 's Republic authorised a further exchange of property between the NORP and GPE : GPE was granted title to a property at CARDINAL Dr FAC in GPE ( see paragraph CARDINAL above ) , owned by GPE , which in return obtained title to CARDINAL detached houses in PERSON ( known as “ LOC ” and “ LOC ” ) and the appurtenant QUANTITY . m of land , owned by ORG .

According to the applicants , “ FAC ” is actually the building in PERSON which belonged to GPE before being requisitioned and subsequently becoming the property of GPE under Decree no . CARDINAL/CARDINAL on nationalisation ( see paragraphs CARDINAL above ) .

CARDINAL . In an undated diplomatic note addressed to ORG in reply to a question from ORG , the GPE embassy in GPE pointed out that under Decree no . DATE issued by President PERSON , ORG had taken over all the rights vested in the GPE in respect of movable and immovable property abroad . It further noted that GPE now had title in GPE to a housing complex and the appurtenant land in PERSON . It stated that that title had been confirmed by ORG decisions of DATE and CARDINAL DATE , by Decree no . DATE issued on CARDINAL DATE by the ORG of ORG of GPE , and by Decree no . CARDINAL issued on CARDINAL DATE by ORG of GPE ( see paragraphs PERSON , DATE and DATE above ) .

CARDINAL . In a letter of DATE , the mayor of PERSON stated in reply to a question from the first applicant that the NORP Federation embassy in GPE was using the building in PERSON that had belonged to GPE ; an appendix to the nationalisation decree indicated that the embassy had gained possession of the building in issue by virtue of an exchange of immovable property between GPE and the GPE .

CARDINAL . In DATE , following the enactment of PERSON no . NORP on the legal status of residential property that had passed into the ownership of GPE , the first applicant , as DATE 's heir , lodged an application for restitution of the building in PERSON with the administrative board established to deal with applications lodged in PERSON pursuant to PERSON no . LANGUAGE ( “ the ORG ” ) .

CARDINAL . In a decision of DATE , ORG allowed his application and ordered the return of all the property in question to him , namely a detached house and the CARDINAL sq . m of land on which it was built .

CARDINAL . A ORG - owned company , ORG , applied to ORG for judicial review of that decision . It argued that the building was not designated as residential and had not been vacant on the date on which PERSON no . DATE had come into force , whereas the PERSON provided that the administrative authorities empowered to apply it could order the return of property to its owners only if those conditions were met . The applicants applied to intervene in the proceedings , seeking to have PERSON 's application dismissed on the ground that the building in issue was not managed by that company .

CARDINAL . In a judgment of CARDINAL DATE , ORG Instance found for the applicants and dismissed the application by PERSON on the ground that that company did not have locus standi since the building was not managed by it . In the absence of an appeal , that judgment became final .

CARDINAL . On an unspecified date the first applicant brought proceedings against ORG and ORG under Articles CARDINAL et seq . of LAW , seeking an order requiring them to execute the administrative decision of DATE by returning the property in issue to him .

Relying on various documents by means of which he intended to prove that DATE was the former owner of the property and that he himself was DATE 's heir , he urged that the restitution should be effective and enforceable against the legal successor of the GPE , notwithstanding the international principles concerning immunity set forth in the DATE Vienna Convention on Diplomatic Relations .

He submitted that it was impossible for the final administrative decision of DATE in his favour to be enforced in the normal manner by bailiffs , in view of the immunity enjoyed by the NORP Federation embassy in GPE with regard to the LOC it occupied . Recapitulating the circumstances in which the property had been taken from GPE , he contended that a domestic statute , Law no . DATE the application of which entailed the return of his property – could not be deprived of effect by securing diplomatic rights to GPE which , moreover , no longer existed .
CARDINAL . The second applicant sought leave to intervene in the proceedings , arguing that as an heir of DATE she had the same rights as the first applicant .

CARDINAL . In a judgment of CARDINAL DATE , ORG allowed the applicants ' applications and ordered the respondent authorities to return the property to them . It noted that the relevant decision of DATE , which had become final , had been given after verification of the legal status of the property and that the respondents could no longer claim that it was administered by the GPE .

CARDINAL . Snagov Town Council appealed against that judgment . It asserted that the building in issue was not owned or administered by it but was used by the NORP Federation embassy , which had informed it that it was the owner of the building in a diplomatic note which ORG submitted in evidence ( see paragraph CARDINAL above ) . Emphasising that it was not contesting the applicants ' title to the building , ORG argued that it lacked the capacity to take the action demanded by the applicants since the property was occupied by the embassy .
ORG argued , lastly , that it was impossible to execute the final decision of DATE , seeing that the bailiffs were also prevented from taking any enforcement measures for similar reasons .

CARDINAL . NORP In a judgment of DATE , ORG allowed ORG appeal , quashed the judgment of ORG and dismissed the applicants ' application as being ill - founded . It noted that the building was not managed by the administrative authorities in question but was used by the NORP Federation embassy in GPE , which had stated in a diplomatic note that it was the owner ( see paragraph CARDINAL above ) . ORG considered that execution of the administrative decision of DATE would amount to breaching the immunity enjoyed by GPE diplomatic mission in GPE , and thus directly undermining the GPE 's fundamental interests . Lastly , it pointed out that immunity from execution was a principle recognised in international law , legal theory and practice .

CARDINAL . The applicants appealed against that judgment , submitting that the lower courts had been incorrect in their interpretation of the evidence and of the nature of the legal relationships in the case before them . They argued , in particular , that the requisitioning of the property in issue and its passing into ORG ownership had been unlawful on the ground that Decree no . CARDINAL on the exchange of property had not been signed and was therefore null and void . They submitted plans showing the location of the property in question and documents concerning the exchange of property between the NORP and GPE ( see paragraphs CARDINAL , CARDINAL , DATE and DATE ) .

CARDINAL . In a judgment of CARDINAL DATE , ORG allowed their appeal , quashed the judgment of DATE and remitted the case to ORG for rehearing . ORG asked the court to conduct additional inquiries in order to ascertain the procedure by which the building had become the property of ORG and had been transferred to GPE , and to clarify the legal status of the building at CARDINAL Dr FAC , GPE , which the GPE had exchanged for the building in issue . The court was also instructed to investigate who had used the building before and after DATE and for what purpose .

CARDINAL . At the hearing on DATE , ORG raised of its own motion the objection that the respondent administrative authorities could not be a party to the proceedings as the property was not managed by them . It joined that objection to the merits .

CARDINAL . In a decision delivered on DATE the court , without having conducted the additional inquiries ordered by ORG , allowed the objection and dismissed the applicants ' action . It noted that the building in issue had initially been requisitioned and then nationalised in the circumstances outlined in DATE above , and that it had subsequently become the property of GPE by means of an exchange between GPE and the GPE , approved by Decree no . CARDINAL of CARDINAL DATE ( see paragraph CARDINAL above ) . Observing that the building was now the property of GPE , the GPE 's legal successor , the court considered that the first applicant 's application for an order requiring the relevant authorities to return the building in accordance with LAW had been brought against entities lacking the capacity to take part in the proceedings .

CARDINAL . The applicants appealed against that judgment , arguing that the court had omitted to take into account either the fact that the property had been taken unlawfully from DATE or the evidence which they had submitted to that effect ( see paragraph CARDINAL in fine above ) .

CARDINAL . In a judgment of DATE , against which no ordinary appeal lay , ORG dismissed their appeal and upheld the judgment of DATE . It noted , firstly , that the applicants ' criticism that the lower court had not taken into account or interpreted correctly the evidence they had submitted was unfounded . It considered in that connection that the building had passed into the ownership of GPE under Decree no . CARDINAL/CARDINAL on nationalisation and that the applicants could accordingly not claim that it had been taken unlawfully by the ORG . It further observed that GPE title to the building in issue had been confirmed and that the lower court had consequently been correct in finding that the applicants ' action was directed against respondents lacking the capacity to take part in the proceedings .

CARDINAL . On DATE the applicants lodged an application to set aside the judgment of DATE . They submitted that ORG had breached LAW by overlooking its previous judgment of CARDINAL DATE in which it had ordered additional inquiries . They added that ORG had omitted to draw any inferences from the evidence they had submitted .

CARDINAL . In a judgment of DATE , against which no ordinary appeal lay , ORG dismissed the applicants ' application as being ill - founded . It observed that in its judgment of CARDINAL DATE it had not dealt with points of law , so that its decision could not have been binding in the new round of proceedings after the case had been remitted ; rather , it had simply requested the lower court to clarify the legal position regarding the building in issue and the entity occupying it . It therefore held that LAW of LAW had not been breached by the lower court . ORG held that the applicants ' second complaint was likewise unfounded , seeing that in its judgment of CARDINAL DATE on the applicants ' appeal it had found that title to the building in question was vested in GPE and not in the respondents , thereby settling the dispute in the light of all the evidence before it .

CARDINAL . On an unspecified date the applicants sent a memorial to the Ambassador of GPE in GPE , requesting him to allow the relevant NORP authorities to return the building in PERSON to them , as they had inherited it and had been granted restitution of it under PERSON no . LANGUAGE . After recapitulating the circumstances that had led to GPE 's loss of the building ( see paragraphs CARDINAL above ) , they argued that the exchange of property between the NORP and GPE under Decree no . CARDINAL of CARDINAL DATE had been unlawful and hence void in that , firstly , the decree concerning the exchange had been neither signed nor published and , secondly , the building offered by GPE in return for the building in PERSON had not belonged to a NORP national , a criterion that would have justified its transfer to the NORP authorities in accordance with the decisions taken at FAC .

The applicants stated , lastly , that they did not wish to be party to a possible dispute with GPE , contending that any such proceedings would be thwarted by the application of the principle of diplomatic immunity enjoyed by the embassy . They argued , however , that that principle should not contravene the domestic legal order , adding that the property in issue was not of any particular practical interest .
CARDINAL . It is not clear from the evidence before the ORG whether the applicants received a reply to their request .

CARDINAL . On an unspecified date the applicants contacted the FAC prefect 's office . Relying on Law no . CARDINAL/CARDINAL on the legal status of immovable property wrongfully seized by ORG DATE and DATE , they sought restitution of the building in PERSON . In a letter of DATE the prefect replied that , by virtue of sections CARDINAL and CARDINAL of Law no . CARDINAL/CARDINAL taken together , the authority responsible for restitution of such property was the entity in possession of the building or the council of the district in which the property was situated . He invited the applicants to contact those authorities through the bailiffs at ORG . There is no indication in the evidence before the ORG as to whether the applicants acted on that recommendation .

CARDINAL . In a letter dated DATE , the representative of GPE at the ORG , in reply to a request for information sent under LAW ( a ) of ORG by the ORG dealing with the case , stated that GPE , as the GPE 's successor in title to all its movable and immovable property abroad , had title in GPE to a housing complex in PERSON and the appurtenant land . He indicated that GPE title to the property had been confirmed by ORG decisions of DATE and CARDINAL DATE , by Decree no . DATE issued on DATE by the Presidium of ORG of GPE , and by Decree no . CARDINAL issued on CARDINAL DATE by ORG of GPE ( see paragraphs PERSON , DATE and DATE above ) , as the GPE embassy in GPE had already informed ORG in a diplomatic note ( see paragraph CARDINAL above ) .
CARDINAL . It appears from the evidence submitted by the applicants that the building in issue is still being used by officials of the GPE embassy in GPE .
CARDINAL . The relevant international provisions are as follows :
“ For the purpose of the present Convention , the following expressions shall have the meanings hereunder assigned to them :

( i ) the ' premises of the mission ' are the buildings or parts of buildings and the land ancillary thereto , irrespective of ownership , used for the purposes of the mission including the residence of the head of the mission . ”
“ CARDINAL . The LOC of the mission shall be inviolable . The agents of the receiving ORG may not enter them , except with the consent of the head of the mission .

CARDINAL . The receiving ORG is under a special duty to take all appropriate steps to protect the LOC of the mission against any intrusion or damage and to prevent any disturbance of the peace of the mission or impairment of its dignity .
CARDINAL . The LOC of the mission , their furnishings and other property thereon and the means of transport of the mission shall be immune from search , requisition , attachment or execution . ”
“ A ORG can not claim immunity from the jurisdiction of a court of ORG if the proceedings relate to :
( a ) its rights or interests in , or its use or possession of , immovable property ; or
( b ) its obligations arising out of its rights or interests in , or use or possession of , immovable property
and the property is situated in the territory of the ORG of the forum . ”

“ No measures of execution or preventive measures against the property of a Contracting State may be taken in the territory of another ORG except where and to the extent that the ORG has expressly consented thereto in writing in any particular case . ”

CARDINAL . On DATE ORG adopted LAW and their Property , requested the Secretary - General as depositary to open it for signature , and invited GPE to become parties to it . The relevant provisions of the convention , which is open for signature from DATE to CARDINAL DATE , read as follows :
“ A ORG enjoys immunity , in respect of itself and its property , from the jurisdiction of the courts of another ORG subject to the provisions of the present Convention . ”

“ CARDINAL . A ORG shall give effect to ORG immunity under LAW by refraining from exercising jurisdiction in a proceeding before its courts against another ORG and to that end shall ensure that its courts determine on their own initiative that the immunity of that other ORG under LAW is respected .
CARDINAL . A proceeding before a court of a ORG shall be considered to have been instituted against another ORG if that other ORG :
( a ) is named as a party to that proceeding ; or
( b ) is not named as a party to the proceeding but the proceeding in effect seeks to affect the property , rights , interests or activities of that other ORG . ”

“ Unless otherwise agreed between the GPE concerned , a ORG can not invoke immunity from jurisdiction before a court of another ORG which is otherwise competent in a proceeding which relates to the determination of :

( a ) any right or interest of the ORG in , or its possession or use of , or any obligation of the ORG arising out of its interest in , or its possession or use of , immovable property situated in the ORG of the forum ;
( b ) any right or interest of the ORG in movable or immovable property arising by way of succession , gift or bona vacantia ; or
( c ) any right or interest of the ORG in the administration of property , such as trust property , the estate of a bankrupt or the property of a company in the event of its winding up . ”
Article DATE State immunity from post - judgment measures of constraint

“ No post - judgment measures of constraint , such as attachment , arrest or execution , against property of a ORG may be taken in connection with a proceeding before a court of another ORG unless and except to the extent that :
( a ) the ORG has expressly consented to the taking of such measures as indicated :
( i ) by international agreement ;
( ii ) by an arbitration agreement or in a written contract ; or
( iii ) by a declaration before the court or by a written communication after a dispute between the parties has arisen ; or
( b ) the ORG has allocated or earmarked property for the satisfaction of the claim which is the object of that proceeding ; or

( c ) it has been established that the property is specifically in use or intended for use by the ORG for other than government non - commercial purposes and is in the territory of the ORG of the forum ... ”

“ No measures of constraint or preventive attachment may be carried out in respect of property belonging to a foreign ORG if the property is used for the performance of activities of its Government not connected with any form of economic exploitation . ”

“ CARDINAL . The property of a foreign ORG is not subject to any process or order of the courts or other organs of the forum ORG for the satisfaction or enforcement of a judgment or order , or for the purpose of prejudgment measures in preparation for execution ( hereafter referred to as measures of constraint ) , except as provided for by this LAW and by LAW .
CARDINAL . NORP The following categories of property of a State in particular are immune from measures of constraint :
( a ) property used or set aside for use by the ORG 's diplomatic or consular missions , its special missions or its missions to international organisations ;

“ CARDINAL . A foreign ORG may not invoke immunity from jurisdiction or from measures of constraint if it has expressly consented to the exercise of the relevant type of jurisdiction by the relevant court or other organs of the forum ORG :
( a ) by international agreement ;
( b ) in a written contract ;
( c ) by a declaration relating to the specific case ;

( d ) by a voluntary submission to jurisdiction in the form of the institution of proceedings in the relevant organs of the forum ORG , or of intervention in proceedings for the purpose of pursuing issues related to the merits of those proceedings , or of a comparable step in the proceedings .
CARDINAL . Consent to the exercise of jurisdiction does not imply consent to measures of constraint , for which separate and explicit consent is required . ”
CARDINAL . NORP The relevant provisions of domestic law are as follows :

“ Individuals who formerly owned residential property which passed lawfully into the ownership of the ORG or of another artificial person after DATE and which was still in the possession of the ORG or another artificial person on DATE shall be entitled to benefit , by way of reparation , from the measures in this PERSON .
The provisions of this PERSON shall apply equally to the successors in title of such former owners , subject to existing statutory provisions . ”

“ The persons referred to in LAW shall be entitled to restitution in the form of the restoration to them of the ownership of flats in which they currently live as tenants or which are vacant . In respect of other flats , those persons shall receive compensation ... ”
“ Persons entitled to claim restitution ... shall lodge an application for such purpose ... ”

“ Applications referred to in section CARDINAL above shall be lodged with the administrative board for the district in which the property is situated . They must include full details of the applicants ' identity , their status as owner or successor in title , ... certified copies of the documents on the basis of which they intend to prove their ownership or that of the deceased person of whom they are successors in title ... Decisions on restitution of property shall be taken by the county council for the district in which the property is situated . ”

“ ... The county board for the application of the provisions of this PERSON shall be composed of : the chairman of the county council , who shall chair the board , the notary public , the head of the county 's public finance and ORG audit department , the head of the county 's town planning , public works and regional development department , the head of the county council 's legal service , and CARDINAL specialists in leasehold improvements and building and land valuation , assisted by a secretary . ”

“ Within DATE of the date on which they receive proposals from the local boards , the county boards shall determine whether the former owners or their successors are entitled to the restitution of their property or to compensation , and shall issue decisions to that effect . Such decisions shall be communicated within DATE to the former owners or their successors in title ... and to the entities in possession of the property ... The boards ' decisions shall be adopted by majority vote . ”
“ Decisions of the county boards ... shall be subject to review by the national courts and may be challenged , in accordance with civil law , within DATE of being communicated . ”

“ ... On the basis of the decision of the county board or , as the case may be , the final judicial decision , the person granted restitution of the property shall apply to be entered in the land register as the owner .
The decision of the county board or , as the case may be , the final judicial decision shall amount to a document of title to the property . ”

“ CARDINAL . The measures provided for in PERSON no . NORP by way of reparation shall be available only to the former owners of residential property which passed lawfully as such into the ownership of the State ... and their successors in title ...

CARDINAL . Residential property which passed lawfully as such into ORG ownership denotes buildings which were nationalised as buildings intended for residential use pursuant to a statutory provision in force on the date on which they passed into ORG ownership , such as Decree no . CARDINAL/CARDINAL ... ”
“ Section CARDINAL [ of PERSON no . LANGUAGE ] shall be supplemented by the following paragraphs :

CARDINAL . Residential property which passed into ORG ownership in breach of the statutory provisions in force on the date in question , or in the absence of any statutory provision forming a legal basis for the ORG 's title to it , shall be deemed to have passed unlawfully into ORG ownership and to fall outside the scope of PERSON no . DATE .

CARDINAL . Property falling outside the scope of PERSON no . DATE and to which the ORG does not have a valid document of title may be the subject of an application for restitution or compensation under the ordinary procedure . ”

“ ( CARDINAL ) ORG property wrongfully seized by the ORG , a cooperative organisation or any other artificial person DATE and DATE and property expropriated under LAW ( Law no . CARDINAL/CARDINAL ) that has not been returned shall be subject to restitution , normally consisting of the return of the property in question , in accordance with the provisions of this LAW .

( CARDINAL ) Where the property can not be returned , alternative measures of redress shall be taken . Such measures may consist of compensation in the form of other items or services offered in exchange by the occupier , subject to the applicant 's consent , the allotment of shares in commercial companies listed on the stock market , securities at face value used exclusively in the privatisation process or pecuniary compensation . ”
“ Every obligation to do or not to do something shall give rise to compensation in the event of non - performance by the obligor . ”
CARDINAL . At the material time Article CARDINAL was worded as follows :
“ Where a judgment has been quashed and remitted to the court below , the decision delivered following an appeal as to points of law shall be binding on the lower court . ”
That provision was amended as follows by Government Emergency Ordinance no . CARDINAL :

“ Where a judgment has been quashed and remitted to the court below , the decision delivered following an appeal as to points of law and the need to take further evidence shall be binding on the lower court . ”
